docs.abstract: Florence Fabricant (Food) column on cooking oysters; recipes (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: CHILLED oysters on the half shell are available year round. But I have long felt that their flavor is best when the water is cold. So I like to stick with the months with an ''R'' and enjoy my oysters in winter. The classic American plate of oysters comes with cocktail sauce, a mixture of ketchup and horseradish. It does not do much for the flavor of a good oyster, masking rather than enhancing its briny, sometimes coppery richness.

headline.main: For Best Oyster Flavor, Stick to Months With R's in Them

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the 10 or so years since arugula has become a supermarket staple and a yuppie cliche, its use is nearly always in salad. But these bitter-tasting greens have other uses. Arugula is excellent wilted in a pasta sauce and can season a verdant risotto. And even on the salad plate more can be done than a mere toss with endive.

headline.main: Not Just for Salad, Arugula Can Also Season Sauce or Risotto

docs.abstract: Article on stir-fried sugar snap peas; recipes; drawings (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: SUGAR SNAP PEAS, in season at farms throughout the region, may be the ultimate convenience vegetable. They are good raw, as a snack or with a dip. Cooking them takes a simple stir-fry and a few seasonings tossed in a skillet. They are a relatively new vegetable, a cross between snow peas and regular garden peas developed in the early 1980's. Brilliant.

headline.main: Stir-Frying Sugar Snap Peas, the Ultimate in Convenience

docs.abstract: Molly O'Neill article on rich desserts served in department store restaurants; recipes; photo (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: Traditionally, tea-room-style restaurants have been tucked behind grand displays of clothing, shoes and hats in department stores. These were genteel spots, places where the ladies-who-shop would meet to deliberate and dream, to refuel. But today, the pneumatic wheeze of espresso machines has become as constant as the beep of electronic cash registers. In fact, lavish displays of elaborate salads, dainty tea sandwiches, sumptuous layer cakes and delectable, buttery cookies are now as important as the impeccably dressed mannequins. Maybe even more important.

docs.abstract: Moira Hodgson article on cooking artichokes; recipes (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: NO one knows artichokes better than Italians, who are endlessly inventive with them. Artichokes are good steamed whole or stuffed and baked, eaten leaf by leaf and not hurried over. They can be added to stews with veal, lamb or chicken or braised with spring vegetables like fava beans, peas, baby carrots or fennel. They are also delicious sauteed and fried in olive oil. Most Americans discard the stalk, which is a pity since it can be as tender and delicate as the heart, once the outer layer is peeled away with a sharp knife.

headline.main: Counting the Ways To Use Artichokes

docs.abstract: Food column describes cooking with pepper; recipes; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: HISTORIANS SPECULATE THAT PEPPER changed the course of European history. These green, black and white berries of the Piper nigrum vine are potent pellets that enhance rather than mask the flavor of food. Lust for them drove Europeans to find trade routes to the East, which should come as no surprise to anyone who cooks. Used wisely, pepper can turn the ordinary into the distinct; in fact, pepper changes everything. But in the kitchen, as in life, pure knowledge is not enough. Wisdom comes from experience. So what do we know about pepper? We know for certain that green peppercorns, which come lightly pickled or freeze-dried, are the mildest incarnation of the unripe fruit. So mild that the vinegar used in pickling them tends to overwhelm their flavor and they must be rinsed before use.

docs.abstract: Molly O'Neill Food column on sweet and savory desserts; recipes; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THERE IS SOMETHING SUBSTANTIAL, ENDURING and perhaps a little frightening about the dark side of sweetness. In a dessert, the interplay of sweet and savory delivers something a lot more satisfying than what mere sugar can provide. Savory sweets seem to occupy an ancient place in our collective memory. They taste of bloodier, grittier times. Maybe it's the bittersweet chocolate the Aztecs once sipped or the pounded fruit-and-nut cakes thatthe Romans brought along on long journeys that make the savory sweet so evocative. Or maybe their associative power is merely a physiological one. If, as Jews do on Rosh ha-Shanah, you dip a slice of apple in honey, the apple will taste tart. A slice of the same apple eaten with tart cheese, in the Yankee fashion, will taste sweet. Just as good needs evil to seem really, really good, and as darkness seems possible only when contrasted with light, discrete taste sensations require their opposites in order to be more fully realized.
